Author: Alright#0419
Content: Where does he 8kb limit come from? Is that the amount of data a single OP_RETURN can store or the amount of data a tx can store in OP_RETURN?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: basically wondering if we can have multiple OP_RETURN outputs with 8kb each

Author: Alright#0419
Content: as long as it's below tx limit

Author: Alright#0419
Content: which is what like 100kb?

Author: Alright#0419
Content: yea so apparently it's possible to mine txs with multiple OP_RETURN outputs in them, but they will be RejectFromMemoryPool'd by vanilla nodes

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: That really doesnt matter, as this chain breaks consensus rules as it is, just change that?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: if using a really massive TX with multiple op_return it will be easier to keep the stream at max badnwidth on the sending side

Author: Alright#0419
Content: Ah so apparently 100kb is just the max for a "standard" tx

Author: Alright#0419
Content: meaning you can mine txs up to the block size, but again they'd be RejectFromMemoryPool'd by vanilla nodes

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @jl777c what do you think is best route to take? Many smaller transactions or smaller amount of massive txs?

Content: current oracles wouldn't support many OP_RETURNS in one tx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just use one opreturn

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 8kb

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dont need to make any changes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: other than fast blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is why i suggested the method i suggested

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you can slam a bunch of 8kb opreturn and get 256kb/sec bandwidth, we can do decentralized streaming

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: getting the right data into the 8kb and reassembling it becomes a dapp level issue

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the webcam video will have some logical size per opreturn and it might be a bit more or less than 8kb, that is ok. there is some leeway

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and it doesnt really give you more bandwidth to have 8kb single opreturns or 100kb multiple opreturns

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what matters is how fast the blocks can confirm (assuming the blocks are full)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: because if the block is full of data, how much does it matter if it is in 8kb increments or 80kb or 800kb?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in fact, you should get slightly higher throughput with the smaller one due to more fitting into a block

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bandwidth stuff doesnt work exactly like other things

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just add "opreturn":"hexstr" at the top of the JSON

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let me check

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: curl --url "http://127.0.0.1:7783" --data "{\"userpass\":\"$userpass\",\"method\":\"withdraw\",\"coin\":\"CHIPS\",\"outputs\":[{\"RHV2As4rox97BuE3LK96vMeNY8VsGRTmBj\":0.0001}],\"opreturn\":\"deadbeef\"}"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the opreturn string just needs to be 8kb worth of hex

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, its a bit more tricky

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I will add it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, in the create txblaster function there are two variables:     int32_t origspendlen; char *passphrase = 0,*opretstr = "deadbeef";

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: opretstr needs to be hex and it will end up in the opreturn (i think)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if that was 8kb worth of hex, then the opreturn will be much bigger, but all you should have to change is the deadbeef

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: verify it works with deadbeef first, then change it and make sure it adapts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the passphrase is disabled via set to 0, but if there is a string then that string would be needed to decrypt it on display of the opreturn

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so to make this work for a live stream, there is a webcam -> (seqid + 8kb) packetizers that then is retrieved from a fifo in the create txblaster, but this is more a tonyL thing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it wont take much time to feed in the right data. the important think is what level of bandwidth we can achieve

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: blackjok3r#3181

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you want to fill it with opreturns, not vouts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the bandwidth is measured in number of opreturns

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any datastream will be encoded into the opreturns

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: so can only have 1 opreturn per vout, and 1 vout per blaster

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: everything else is overhead
